title: It’s time for a ‘flight to quality’ - Thrive founder Daniel Jacobs

rawLines.text: [Music]
Hello and welcome to the CryptoBeep. My
name is Tim Copeland. I'm the block's
head of growth. Joining me today, we
have Daniel Jacobs, founder and CEO of
Thrive Protocol. Welcome to the show.
How you doing? I'm doing great. It's
great to be here, Tim. Amazing. Before
we get started, just a quick note. If
you are hiring in crypto, you should use
Campus out of all your candidates. Help
you pick out the real crypto natives.
Head to the
block.co/campus to get a three-month
free trial. Now, today's episode is
around crypto grants funding. That's
obviously something that Thrive is
particularly focused on. So what is
Thrive?
Yeah. So um Thrive is you know at this
point we believe the biggest builder
protocol in the space. We support over
$und00 million and committed capital
allocations from a lot of the top chains
in the space. And we support builders
and founders and very quickly working uh
in crypto and and with top chains and
working in a way that creates value that
that creates GDP for the ecosystems that
they support.
And where did the idea for Thrive come
from? Like what what inspired it? Yeah.
So I got into crypto way back in 2013. I
read Satoshi's white paper and I was
really inspired by what I believed was a
treatise on fairness. This idea that
with this big open transparent database,
it doesn't matter who you are or where
you are or what your background is, if
you create value, you can and should and
will be rewarded proportionate to the
value you create. Um, but I also believe
that there was a problem with the
blockchain because the blockchain is
great at validating that a transaction
is valid, proving validity of a
transaction, but it's not great at
proving value. And I believed even way
back in 2013 that something like Thrive
would need to exist to help
decentralized communities to really
deeply um understand that value was
created and be able to reward it. So
even in November of 2013, I registered
the domain for Thrive. But it turns out
I was running another organization at
that time, it would take another eight
and a half years to sell that company,
another few months for a friend to go on
a walk with the beach with me. And and
he said, "Yo, Daniel, whatever happened
to that Thrive idea of yours?" And I
wondered who had built it. And so I went
back and looked and nobody had. And I
realized that I had to found another
organization. And that was kind of the
beginning of Thrive. Cool. So, so you
were sort of aware of crypto since 2013,
but what point um were you actively
involved? Like did you did you stay
active throughout that time? Um what was
your journey like? Yeah, I've been
actively involved since about four years
ago when when I founded Thrive. Um I had
been involved in crypto in different
ways um beforehand, but certainly not
running a business. This this is the
first project, the first organization
that I've been a part of within the
context of of crypto. And you know, some
backgrounds on kind of what Thrive does.
We we actually built kind of a a
product, a protocol that addresses sort
of that major problem that I noticed way
back in 2013. So the protocol is called
Thrive Protocol. And what it does is it
proves that value uh has occurred. And
the way that it works is when somebody
creates something of value, they submit
evidence for that through the protocol
and that evidence is routed to some
number of either certified experts,
people who are capable of reviewing
whatever that evidence is, data or code
or financial information and also some
number of AI agents that score in the
upper cortile of accuracy of those
experts and when a threshold of them
agreed the value is created then a thing
is paid out and it's attested to on
chain. And what that allows for is it
allows foundations and decentralized
crypto communities for the first time to
make investments uh in you know not just
a few teams or people and know that
they're going to create value aligned
with what they promise but in dozens or
hundreds theoretically even thousands of
teams and know that they effectively
have 100% capital efficiency with those
investments. We really believe that it's
been gamechanging in the space.
Sure. So, how does that work in terms of
the people that review the uh
investments like do they get paid for
it? What's their incentive? That's
exactly right. So um they they get paid
in um you know depending on uh the
orientation of the review. It could be
in um uh different currencies of the
communities that we support uh or now
that um they are also earning Thrive
points as they go too. But they only get
paid when they accurately review. So
they're heavily incentivized to review
accurately.
And who reviews the reviewers?
So um anybody can challenge a uh the
outcome of review. Um a reviewer who um
supposedly did not review accurately or
even the recipient. Uh so the
contributor or the builder uh whose
product was uh being reviewed and that
is effectively reviewed by another level
of reviewers who um uh did not
participate in the original review and
have a level of accuracy that um
entitles them to let's call it a special
badge special access.
Okay. So you go to sort of a hierarchy
of review
and uh at what point did you start
introducing AI agents to the mix? If we
go back a year, we started to play
around with AI agents and that was a
very very small part of the process. It
was you know essentially all humans.
Today um it's effectively flipped. So
90% plus of reviews are done by AI
agents and um around 10% of reviews are
done by certified experts who um are you
know highly capable of of reviewing and
and against whom the AI agents accuracy
is being uh judged as well. Sure. And
how does um an AI agent review this
fully? So let's say the person's
claiming oh I've gone and built the the
protocol it's got so many users. How do
they prove that in a way that they the
AI agent can actually verify it like
properly? Yeah, I mean there has to be
um you know a very quantitative
understanding of exactly what it is
that's supposed to be reviewed and the
agent has to have access to uh that
information in order to do the review.
Um, so it's really important that um,
when framing what needs to be reviewed
that that's being framed as accurately
and directly as possible. And why did
you end up like how come you've got to
the point where it's 90% of agents
reviewing it? Is it just because it's
more
efficient? What what sort of led to
that? I mean, one of the really
interesting things that we noticed was
um great reviewers like experts um they
tend to review at an accuracy rate of
um my accuracy rate currently after
hundreds of reviews is 91%. U maybe it's
crept up to 92, right? And when we first
started playing around with AI agents,
they were reviewing significantly worse
than great reviewers. That's changed
quite a bit. Right? So now their
accuracy rate um uh is generally
extremely high. Again, it's um as high
or higher than top experts. So with some
agents, we're seeing 95 96 97% accuracy.
And so really it was just a question of
efficacy. Um we want to be sure that at
scale um uh work products are being paid
fairly. And to be paid fairly, they need
to be reviewed fairly. and um being
reviewed fairly, you know, is is really
it's really a question of accuracy
whether we're talking about humans or
agents that are trained by humans. Okay.
And what sort of um AI are you using for
this like in terms of like which
platforms and then as you are you
modifying the AI or are you just giving
it custom instructions in order you know
to make it effective? Yeah. So um we're
constantly testing um you know different
agents or different platforms against
each other. We're agnostic about the
agent or the modality. Um really the
only thing that we care about is
accuracy and um and
so Thrive being agnostic to to modality
it's it's really important for us to
continuously test and that will always
be the case.
How do you confirm the accuracy?
Right. So the accuracy initially is
confirmed because um there are a
threshold of experts and agents that
effectively find agreements and
depending on the type of thing being
reviewed that threshold can be
different. I mean on average usually
it's around
70% but in some cases you want that
threshold to be as much as 90% or you
know even 100%. So um so that's that's
how we do the confirmation initially. If
it's the case that there's disagreement
for whatever reason, then it can be
doubly confirmed and you know then it
goes to sort of a higher review process.
Additionally, um the contributors or the
builders who are submitting evidence,
they're always getting feedback, right,
from those those reviewers about um why
it is that uh whatever let's say the
milestone was that was confirmed was
actually confirmed or why it was not
confirmed and you know how they can uh
improve their work product, resubmit and
get the confirmation that they're
looking for. What's the biggest check?
Yeah, go for it if you like. Well, I was
going to kind of um switch over to the
other side, which is really interesting
um component of the work we do. So, when
when Thrive started, right, you know,
I'd been thinking about this protocol
for years before we um began to build
it. And so, we had a sense that the
technology was likely going to be
effective in um orienting toward and and
um guaranteeing a level of capital
efficiency that is fundamentally
distinct in the space. That was cool.
The piece that we didn't expect was
that, you know, we have kind of
implicitly created um this social graph
of top builders and and teams and and
founders um that work through Thrive and
in many ways kind of prefer to onboard
into crypto through Thrive. And that has
been a really unexpected piece. And what
we learned is effectively this. When
builders come into crypto or even
builders who are in crypto, if if you're
a builder and you want to work
full-time, it's really hard to do that,
right? You don't just have to be a
builder if you want to get funded um by,
you know, top ecosystems in the space.
You also have to be an insider, a
salesperson, a diplomat, be willing to
go months without being paid sometimes.
Um, you know, be potentially publicly
humiliated on Twitter if you get onto
the wrong Twitter space, right? And if
you're a great builder and you're
working at Google, why would you go into
crypto? And the answer for many builders
is it doesn't make any sense, right? Um,
that's why they're somewhere around
7,200 full-time builders in crypto and
they're around 30 million full-time
builders, I mean developers in the
world, right? So, Thrive made it a lot
easier for, you know, founders and
creators and builders to onboard into
top ecosystems in crypto because what
they do is they effectively apply for an
ecosystem within 7 days because we have
such a fastforwarded process. they're
able to get a yes or no answer within
three days after that they can be
building. And so we've made the process
of onboarding into crypto, of getting
paid for actually building and not being
all these other things, a salesperson or
develop. We made that process so much
easier and it's allowed us to fund, you
know, we've funded at this at this point
over 1500 top teams and builders and
creators uh in the space and you know
it's been a really exciting kind of
accidental
um uh addition to to the experience that
we've had here. Okay. And you talk about
um sort of its role in it with regards
to mind share and also community
building. Would you say there's sort of
some comparisons with Kao? Like
obviously that's you know it's very
popular right now as as sort of a
marketing tool. Yeah. I mean you know I
I see Kaido as by the way I love what
Kaido is doing. Thrive has a Kaido
leaderboard. Um you know I think there's
a lot of really interesting things that
we can do adjacent uh to to Kaido. I see
Kaido as um really wanting to own this
space of being the intelligence layer in
crypto, of being, you know, I think what
they call the the mind share layer in
crypto. Um you know, Thrive, we're we
believe that our opportunity is to to
build and create the first like really
true GDP layer in crypto. um you know we
fund uh effectively projects when they
create value in line with the needs of
ecosystems right and uh in crypto
there's a lot of hype around a lot of
stuff but very little actual value being
created and um so we we really believe
that we have the opportunity to to
create a GDP layer and I think that sits
really nicely alongside a a a mindshare
uh layer that that Kaido attempting to
build right now. And you say it's been
around for four years. How has the sort
of growth been during that time? Like
has it sort of picked up more recently?
Has it changed at all? Yeah, so we were
um initially founded in September of
2021 and so it's been almost four years.
In a couple months will be four years
and it's been an incredible experience.
I mean we have continued to almost
double or almost double quarter over
quarter for I think 10 straight
quarters. Um we have been really lucky
to
support a lot of the top ecosystems in
the space and um the committed capital
or token allocations that go through
drive have continued to grow and grow
and grow and we expect the same at the
end of the day. I mean, there are
different ways to grow in crypto. Um, a
lot of projects grow through marketing
and and hype and market positioning.
Thrive thought about things differently.
We, you know, we didn't say a lot. We
put our hard hats on, you know, brought
our lunch pals to school and did work
every day. And, you know, it's been nice
to see that it's paying off and that
we're able to support so many ecosystems
in really meaningful ways. Yeah. if
you're that like you know well connected
to all of these ecosystems have you
wondered about creating a a venture
capital fund on the side?
It's a really interesting question
because you know somewhere probably a
couple quarters ago people started you
know thinking of us almost as as venture
firms because we funded so many projects
right
um so the answer is no we haven't
thought about creating a venture fund on
the side in reality we actually partner
with a lot of venture funds because when
venture funds um uh you know fund great
teams and and builders and put them in
their portfolios they they want those
builders to be able to have access to
and build in the top ecosystems in the
space and um we are a direct way in
which great builders can have access and
get paid appropriately. Um so right now
we really enjoy our partnerships with
the the venture firms that that we and
the accelerators and the incubators that
that we partner with. um we see
ourselves as again occupying a slightly
different space um seeking to build this
GDP layer of crypto and you know in the
in the future um we hope to just
continue to expand those partnerships.
What are the biggest challenges to
managing grant funding? First I'll start
at the builder level. I mean I'll talk
about a couple different challenges. Um
I'll start it at the builder level.
Unfortunately, I believe that builders
in large part in in in crypto who work
through
ecosystems have been um socialized to um
think oftentimes in a grant farming kind
of way, right? It's so hard to kind of
figure out your way through the system
and and you know get funding from an
ecosystem. oftentimes getting funding is
the victory as opposed to creating value
particularly because historically
um there hasn't been a lot of incentive
to actually create value um getting
funding is 98% of the battle and so um
on the builder side I think there is a
little bit of reimagination that needs
to occur like um builders you know have
the opportunity to kind of close their
eyes and understand that we can make
this industry operate in a way that
looks a lot like all the other ecos, all
the other industries that have boomed
kind of in history where um uh together
we need to think about what it means to
build something of significant value
that can scale, right? Which is not how
a lot of builders who go through the
grant process today think. Um we're
trying to support that reimagination
because it's connected to the way in
which funding is unlocked with Thrive.
Builders get funds when they create
value in line with the needs of
ecosystems, right? So there's direct and
and they don't have to be insiders,
right? They don't have to be anything
but great builders. Um, you know, on the
ecosystem side, I think there's a um
there's a real opportunity to uh
collectively close their eyes and really
deeply understand what they want. The
way in which ecosystems historically
have um created a lot of quote unquote
value um at least token value right is
by creating hype and a lot of BS metrics
right and that works for the short term
but it actually doesn't drive
sustainability in ecosystems or in
crypto as a whole for the long term or
even frankly the medium term. And so
from an ecosystem perspective, um
there's, you know, a real opportunity to
kind of think about what it means to
build and create and commit to
sustainable value for the medium and
long term. And you know, I think when we
have builders who are building for value
creation and we have ecosystems that are
really committed to funding true value
creation over time as opposed to
short-term hype metrics, then you know
we are starting to talk about a crypto
ecosystem that can drive um uh real GDP
um real value um that can invite more
than 7,200 full-time builders and so on
and so forth.
Are there any ecosystems that you think
have done really well at that?
Most of the ecosystems that we're
working with are committed to that in
one way or another because that's, you
know, there that's practically our sales
pitch, right? Um, and so I think that
what we're noticing is that there is
more and more ecosystem commitment to
that on an ongoing basis. I mean, one of
our um ecosystem partners is Zion, and I
had, you know, a a wonderful
conversation yesterday with um somebody
in their foundation named named Z about
exactly that. What does it mean to fund
builders who create real value? Because
our commitment is to real value for the
medium and long term, right? And very
consistently I'm I'm hearing that
directionally that's where foundations,
you know, are going and frankly that's
where they need to go. not not just for,
you know, the the sake of their
community or let's say their their token
price for for the medium and long term,
but but really for the sake of an
industry that has the opportunity to be
like one of two fundamentally
gamechanging industries in humanity
right alongside AI. But to do it, we
need the the real talent in this
industry to not focus on um uh value
extraction and instead to be focused on
creating and adding value to the system.
Yeah. Do you think the sort of issue of
value extraction is one of the biggest
um issues in crypto? Sort of one of the
biggest things preventing it from
growing even further. Absolutely. I
mean, if you're a great mind coming into
crypto, I'm oversimplifying here, but
you have two choices, and this is a
really hard one. Choice number two,
choice number one is um you can make a
lot of money in the short term by
extracting value from the
ecosystem. And that's what most great
minds coming into crypto do. And it
makes sense, right? they can set their
families up, you know, themselves, their
communities up with generational wealth
for, you know, in a very short amount of
time. And choice number two is that they
can build something of real enduring
value, right? That also creates a lot of
wealth for them, but is way
harder and takes a lot
longer. And with most human beings,
that's a difficult decision set, right?
with with most human beings, even good
human beings, they choose choice number
one, right? It's easier, right? Um
there's a very clear short-term path.
And you know, when crypto gets enough
people choosing choice number two, it's
going to create enormous value, much
more value than we could create with
choice number one. But we've got to get
there.
Do you think it's changed over the
years? I feel like I want to say 2017,
2018. Okay. Obviously 2017 you had the
ICO rush, you had a lot of people
wanting to to extract value, but I feel
in general there were a lot of builders
back then who were far more egalitarian
who who sort of really wanted to
um I think just promote really like
healthy growth. Do you think it's
changed much over the years? I do think
you see a lot
of everyone being focused on value
extraction these days, right? um even if
it's not as blatant as the sort of ICO
mania. I mean I it's pretty sad. I I
have a really good friend who is a
venture capitalist and this person has a
portfolio
of 150 or so um investments that they've
made over a number of years and they you
know they were diamond hands, right?
And um recently they told me that they
came to the
conclusion that the only good option is
to as quickly as possible
sell, right? And um that's a problem
when you have people who have been in
the ecosystem for years and years and
years and years, right? Who who have
been committed to the projects that
they've been a part of. And eventually
they they realize that if they're going
to make any money in this
industry, they have to figure out how to
stop supporting those projects for the
medium and long term, right? And I see a
lot of people who have been in crypto
for a while who eventually become
exasperated with the space. They realize
that they have to, you know, do the same
kinds of things that have worked for
others, but they understood were bad for
the industry. And um you know
and it's important for us to notice that
and it's important for us to you know go
wait a second there's something wrong
with a lot. There's something wrong with
the way historically we've been thinking
about
tokconomics. there's something, you
know, wrong with um the way that we've
been thinking about how venture
capitalists win, you know, when they
invest in projects, right? Because often
times for venture capitalists to make
money off a project, they have to dump
the token and there's not enough
liquidity to support that project. And
so the venture capitalist wins but the
project loses and um that is an
occurrence that is very very common in
our space but um that we need to figure
out how to create a different path. So
there's a lot broken that we need to fix
and unfortunately people who have been
around for a while have been seeing it
for a while. There was a bit of
controversy a while ago over whether or
not VCs were good or bad for the space u
because obviously they do provide a lot
of funding and provide a lot of support
but ultimately their goal you know
reasonably is to extract more value than
they put in right I was curious you do
you have a view on on VCs overall
um VCs in crypto tend not to act like
VCs in other industries right they
almost act more like hedge funds And um
you know, one of the things that I've
noticed in general about VCs in crypto
is um that in general they're not
looking for real businesses that can
create GDP for the industry, that can
create real value for the industry.
They're looking for hype machines that,
you know, they can sell the token as
quickly as possible and make some money.
It's hard for me to call that a VC,
right? Like in our industry, we call
them, they call themselves VCs, you
know, um, etc. But, you know, real
venture capitalists that, you know, help
support and build new industries and
reap the rewards and benefits, what they
do is they support great founders and
great projects for the medium and long
term, right? And when those projects win
in a really big way, they win in a
really big way, too. We don't have
enough of that in crypto. If we had more
of that in crypto, um, you know, I think
we'd see more sustainability in the
ecosystem.
I do think the problem is is the fact
that the the main goal is typically to
get tokens as opposed to equity because
I think the problem with a lot of tokens
is partly due to the massively
increasing number of tokens across the
massively increasing number of
blockchains. there's so much dilution,
it's just hard for tokens to to remain
to to to keep their value or to increase
their value in the long run. And then in
particular, even with well very popular
projects that might be very widely used
and have very good reputation in crypto,
the token price doesn't necessarily
reflect that because partly because, you
know, if it's a if it's a arguably
pointless governance token, it's not
capturing any of the value of the
success of the protocol. it can go in a
complete opposite direction to the
actual growth of the protocol. So in a
way it's you're not
necessarily aligned with the success of
the project in a way that I think
typically you are if you have equity.
Yeah, I I I I I would agree with you and
um you know, I think that there is a
real opportunity amongst the other
problems that we talked about that need
to be fixed to ensure that token value
is aligned with project value. Right?
It's a simple thing to say, but
historically for regulatory reasons and
other, right, it's been a really hard
thing to do. And hopefully as we get
more clarity in the regulatory landscape
um we can start um really aligning those
two pieces for most projects better. And
hopefully that'll help. And you're
right. I mean, you know, when the pool
is only so big, but you know, the number
of tokens are increasing at such, you
know, a massive rate on on almost a
daily basis, it creates all kinds of
issues, right? Um, from that that impact
the viability of even good projects.
Yeah, I definitely think once you get
um rewards
uh revenue sharing starts becoming much
more commonplace, I think it then
becomes much more interesting in buying
tokens that you think are associated
with projects that you think are have
really good fundamentals. Um, and I
think that becomes almost like the
opposite of the memecoin cycle where you
just, you know, whatever captures the
attention spam of the moment, you know,
very short-term trading. You then
suddenly actually, you know, start to
think which which protocol is going to
be here in 5 years time and how can I
get a percentage of the fees it's going
to make. Um, yeah, I think we start to
see some people call it fundamental
season. Yeah, I I totally agree. We we
believe very strongly that now is the
time in crypto for a flight to reality,
for a flight to quality, um for a flight
to fundamentals. Um, that's I it's it's
very connected to why Thrive exists and
why I believe that we have grown as
quickly as we've we've grown because we
back projects with real fundamentals and
we make sure that they're funded, you
know, as um they achieve uh you know,
real credible
um revenue milestones, TDL milestones,
growth milestones that are
supportive of the future of that
project, of the ecosystems, you know, in
which they are exist. testing and also
crypto as a whole. Something I like to
ask people, what um crypto platforms or
or protocols have you been playing
around with or experimenting with
recently? Yeah, I mean um beyond
Thrive. Um so look within the Thrive
ecosystem there's like so much cool
stuff. I I talked earlier about Zion.
We're working with with Polygon and and
with Hideera funding a bunch of stuff
on, you know, on both of them. There's a
lot of um preTGE stuff that we're going
to be launching soon that we're really
really excited about like um you know
Far Away is and and Fchain um and you
know be life which is a really
interesting kind of Bitcoin layer 2 um
and you know and a bunch of others. I
mean we've just um ZK Verify which is a
new ZK chain um connected to kind of a
sister of of Horizon and and Zen. We
just think that there's so much really
interesting stuff in the space that's
that's happening right now. And it's
been really interesting to be alongside
it and to ask a a deeper question which
is like, you know, who are the great
teams and builders and founders that can
help build and support and, you know,
and and help grow. For sure. And what do
you think will be the biggest trend of
2025? H I think hope I hope I hope we've
nailed it together which is um you know
a a flight to value to quality to GDP to
great builders and founders and you know
generally speaking to to people who are
committed to building the future of
crypto we need it and now is the time.
Amazing. And on that high note that's
all we have for today. Uh, I want to
thank Daniel for joining this episode.
And as a reminder, a newsroom works
tirelessly to get you accurate, informed
crypto news. If you want to stay ahead,
read the blog. Thanks and see you next
time. Thanks, Tim.
[Music]
[Music]

cleanText:
[Music]

Hello and welcome to the CryptoBeep. My name is Tim Copeland. I'm The Block's head of growth. Joining me today, we have Daniel Jacobs, founder and CEO of Thrive Protocol. Welcome to the show. How you doing?

I'm doing great. It's great to be here, Tim.

Amazing. Before we get started, just a quick note. If you are hiring in crypto, you should use Campus out of all your candidates. Help you pick out the real crypto natives. Head to the block.co/campus to get a three-month free trial. Now, today's episode is around crypto grants funding. That's obviously something that Thrive is particularly focused on. So what is Thrive?

Yeah. So, um, Thrive is, you know, at this point, we believe the biggest builder protocol in the space. We support over $100 million in committed capital allocations from a lot of the top chains in the space. And we support builders and founders and very quickly working, uh, in crypto and and with top chains and working in a way that creates value, that that creates GDP for the ecosystems that they support.

And where did the idea for Thrive come from? Like, what, what inspired it?

Yeah. So I got into crypto way back in 2013. I read Satoshi's white paper and I was really inspired by what I believed was a treatise on fairness. This idea that with this big open transparent database, it doesn't matter who you are or where you are or what your background is, if you create value, you can and should and will be rewarded proportionate to the value you create. Um, but I also believe that there was a problem with the blockchain because the blockchain is great at validating that a transaction is valid, proving validity of a transaction, but it's not great at proving value. And I believed even way back in 2013 that something like Thrive would need to exist to help decentralized communities to really deeply um understand that value was created and be able to reward it. So even in November of 2013, I registered the domain for Thrive. But it turns out I was running another organization at that time, it would take another eight and a half years to sell that company, another few months for a friend to go on a walk with the beach with me. And and he said, "Yo, Daniel, whatever happened to that Thrive idea of yours?" And I wondered who had built it. And so I went back and looked and nobody had. And I realized that I had to found another organization. And that was kind of the beginning of Thrive.

Cool. So, so you were sort of aware of crypto since 2013, but at what point um were you actively involved? Like, did you did you stay active throughout that time? Um, what was your journey like?

Yeah, I've been actively involved since about four years ago when when I founded Thrive. Um, I had been involved in crypto in different ways um beforehand, but certainly not running a business. This this is the first project, the first organization that I've been a part of within the context of of crypto. And you know, some backgrounds on kind of what Thrive does. We we actually built kind of a a product, a protocol that addresses sort of that major problem that I noticed way back in 2013. So the protocol is called Thrive Protocol. And what it does is it proves that value uh has occurred. And the way that it works is when somebody creates something of value, they submit evidence for that through the protocol and that evidence is routed to some number of either certified experts, people who are capable of reviewing whatever that evidence is, data or code or financial information and also some number of AI agents that score in the upper quartile of accuracy of those experts and when a threshold of them agreed the value is created then a thing is paid out and it's attested to on chain. And what that allows for is it allows foundations and decentralized crypto communities for the first time to make investments uh in you know not just a few teams or people and know that they're going to create value aligned with what they promise but in dozens or hundreds theoretically even thousands of teams and know that they effectively have 100% capital efficiency with those investments. We really believe that it's been gamechanging in the space.

Sure. So, how does that work in terms of the people that review the uh investments? Like, do they get paid for it? What's their incentive?

That's exactly right. So, um, they they get paid in um, you know, depending on uh the orientation of the review. It could be in um uh different currencies of the communities that we support uh or now that um they are also earning Thrive points as they go too. But they only get paid when they accurately review. So they're heavily incentivized to review accurately.

And who reviews the reviewers?

So, um, anybody can challenge a uh the outcome of review. Um, a reviewer who um supposedly did not review accurately or even the recipient. Uh, so the contributor or the builder uh whose product was uh being reviewed and that is effectively reviewed by another level of reviewers who um uh did not participate in the original review and have a level of accuracy that um entitles them to let's call it a special badge, special access.

Okay. So you go to sort of a hierarchy of review.

And uh at what point did you start introducing AI agents to the mix?

If we go back a year, we started to play around with AI agents and that was a very, very small part of the process. It was, you know, essentially all humans. Today, um, it's effectively flipped. So 90% plus of reviews are done by AI agents and um, around 10% of reviews are done by certified experts who um, are you know, highly capable of of reviewing and and against whom the AI agents accuracy is being uh, judged as well.

Sure. And how does um an AI agent review this fully? So let's say the person's claiming, oh, I've gone and built the the protocol, it's got so many users. How do they prove that in a way that they the AI agent can actually verify it like properly?

Yeah, I mean there has to be um, you know, a very quantitative understanding of exactly what it is that's supposed to be reviewed and the agent has to have access to uh that information in order to do the review. Um, so it's really important that um, when framing what needs to be reviewed that that's being framed as accurately and directly as possible.

And why did you end up like, how come you've got to the point where it's 90% of agents reviewing it? Is it just because it's more efficient? What, what sort of led to that?

I mean, one of the really interesting things that we noticed was um, great reviewers like experts, um, they tend to review at an accuracy rate of 93%, 94%, 95%. Um, my accuracy rate currently after hundreds of reviews is 91%. U maybe it's crept up to 92, right? And when we first started playing around with AI agents, they were reviewing significantly worse than great reviewers. That's changed quite a bit. Right? So now their accuracy rate um uh is generally extremely high. Again, it's um as high or higher than top experts. So with some agents, we're seeing 95, 96, 97% accuracy. And so really it was just a question of efficacy. Um, we want to be sure that at scale um uh work products are being paid fairly. And to be paid fairly, they need to be reviewed fairly. And um being reviewed fairly, you know, is is really it's really a question of accuracy whether we're talking about humans or agents that are trained by humans.

Okay. And what sort of um AI are you using for this? Like, in terms of like which platforms and then as you are you modifying the AI or are you just giving it custom instructions in order you know, to make it effective?

Yeah. So, um, we're constantly testing um, you know, different agents or different platforms against each other. We're agnostic about the agent or the modality. Um, really the only thing that we care about is accuracy and um, and so Thrive being agnostic to to modality, it's it's really important for us to continuously test and that will always be the case.

How do you confirm the accuracy?

Right. So the accuracy initially is confirmed because um there are a threshold of experts and agents that effectively find agreements and depending on the type of thing being reviewed that threshold can be different. I mean on average usually it's around 70%, but in some cases you want that threshold to be as much as 90% or you know, even 100%. So, um, so that's that's how we do the confirmation initially. If it's the case that there's disagreement for whatever reason, then it can be doubly confirmed and you know, then it goes to sort of a higher review process. Additionally, um, the contributors or the builders who are submitting evidence, they're always getting feedback, right, from those those reviewers about um, why it is that uh, whatever let's say the milestone was that was confirmed was actually confirmed or why it was not confirmed and you know, how they can uh, improve their work product, resubmit and get the confirmation that they're looking for.

What's the biggest check?

Yeah, go for it if you like.

Well, I was going to kind of um, switch over to the other side, which is a really interesting um, component of the work we do. So, when when Thrive started, right, you know, I'd been thinking about this protocol for years before we um, began to build it. And so, we had a sense that the technology was likely going to be effective in um, orienting toward and and um, guaranteeing a level of capital efficiency that is fundamentally distinct in the space. That was cool. The piece that we didn't expect was that, you know, we have kind of implicitly created um, this social graph of top builders and and teams and and founders um, that work through Thrive and in many ways kind of prefer to onboard into crypto through Thrive. And that has been a really unexpected piece. And what we learned is effectively this. When builders come into crypto or even builders who are in crypto, if if you're a builder and you want to work full-time, it's really hard to do that, right? You don't just have to be a builder if you want to get funded um, by, you know, top ecosystems in the space. You also have to be an insider, a salesperson, a diplomat, be willing to go months without being paid sometimes. Um, you know, be potentially publicly humiliated on Twitter if you get onto the wrong Twitter space, right? And if you're a great builder and you're working at Google, why would you go into crypto? And the answer for many builders is it doesn't make any sense, right? Um, that's why they're somewhere around 7,200 full-time builders in crypto and they're around 30 million full-time builders, I mean developers in the world, right? So, Thrive made it a lot easier for, you know, founders and creators and builders to onboard into top ecosystems in crypto because what they do is they effectively apply for an ecosystem within 7 days because we have such a fastforwarded process. they're able to get a yes or no answer within three days after that they can be building. And so we've made the process of onboarding into crypto, of getting paid for actually building and not being all these other things, a salesperson or develop. We made that process so much easier and it's allowed us to fund, you know, we've funded at this at this point over 1500 top teams and builders and creators uh in the space and you know, it's been a really exciting kind of accidental um uh addition to to the experience that we've had here.

Okay. And you talk about um sort of its role in it with regards to mind share and also community building. Would you say there's sort of some comparisons with Kaito? Like, obviously that's you know, it's very popular right now as as sort of a marketing tool.

Yeah. I mean, you know, I I see Kaito as, by the way, I love what Kaito is doing. Thrive has a Kaito leaderboard. Um, you know, I think there's a lot of really interesting things that we can do adjacent uh to to Kaito. I see Kaito as um, really wanting to own this space of being the intelligence layer in crypto, of being, you know, I think what they call the the mind share layer in crypto. Um, you know, Thrive, we're we believe that our opportunity is to to build and create the first like really true GDP layer in crypto. um, you know, we fund uh effectively projects when they create value in line with the needs of ecosystems, right? And uh, in crypto, there's a lot of hype around a lot of stuff, but very little actual value being created. And um, so we we really believe that we have the opportunity to to create a GDP layer and I think that sits really nicely alongside a a a mindshare uh layer that that Kaito is attempting to build right now.

And you say it's been around for four years. How has the sort of growth been during that time? Like, has it sort of picked up more recently? Has it changed at all?

Yeah, so we were um, initially founded in September of 2021 and so it's been almost four years. In a couple months will be four years and it's been an incredible experience. I mean, we have continued to almost double or almost double quarter over quarter for I think 10 straight quarters. Um, we have been really lucky to support a lot of the top ecosystems in the space and um, the committed capital or token allocations that go through drive have continued to grow and grow and grow and we expect the same at the end of the day. I mean, there are different ways to grow in crypto. Um, a lot of projects grow through marketing and and hype and market positioning. Thrive thought about things differently. We, you know, we didn't say a lot. We put our hard hats on, you know, brought our lunch pals to school and did work every day. And, you know, it's been nice to see that it's paying off and that we're able to support so many ecosystems in really meaningful ways.

Yeah. If you're that like, you know, well connected to all of these ecosystems, have you wondered about creating a a venture capital fund on the side?

It's a really interesting question because, you know, somewhere probably a couple quarters ago, people started, you know, thinking of us almost as as venture firms because we funded so many projects, right? Um, so the answer is no, we haven't thought about creating a venture fund on the side. In reality, we actually partner with a lot of venture funds because when venture funds um uh, you know, fund great teams and and builders and put them in their portfolios, they they want those builders to be able to have access to and build in the top ecosystems in the space and um, we are a direct way in which great builders can have access and get paid appropriately. Um, so right now, we really enjoy our partnerships with the the venture firms that that we and the accelerators and the incubators that that we partner with. um, we see ourselves as again, occupying a slightly different space, um, seeking to build this GDP layer of crypto and you know, in the in the future, um, we hope to just continue to expand those partnerships.

What are the biggest challenges to managing grant funding? First, I'll start at the builder level. I mean, I'll talk about


A couple different challenges.
I'll start it at the builder level.
Unfortunately, I believe that builders in large part in crypto who work through ecosystems have been socialized to think oftentimes in a grant farming kind of way, right?
It's so hard to kind of figure out your way through the system and get funding from an ecosystem.
Oftentimes getting funding is the victory as opposed to creating value, particularly because historically there hasn't been a lot of incentive to actually create value.
Getting funding is 98% of the battle, and so on the builder side, I think there is a little bit of reimagination that needs to occur.
Builders, you know, have the opportunity to kind of close their eyes and understand that we can make this industry operate in a way that looks a lot like all the other ecos, all the other industries that have boomed kind of in history where together we need to think about what it means to build something of significant value that can scale, right?
Which is not how a lot of builders who go through the grant process today think.
We're trying to support that reimagination because it's connected to the way in which funding is unlocked with Thrive Protocol.
Builders get funds when they create value in line with the needs of ecosystems, right?
So there's direct, and they don't have to be insiders, right?
They don't have to be anything but great builders.
On the ecosystem side, I think there's a real opportunity to collectively close their eyes and really deeply understand what they want.
The way in which ecosystems historically have created a lot of quote unquote value, at least token value, right, is by creating hype and a lot of BS metrics, right?
And that works for the short term, but it actually doesn't drive sustainability in ecosystems or in Crypto as a whole for the long term or even frankly the medium term.
And so from an ecosystem perspective, there's a real opportunity to kind of think about what it means to build and create and commit to sustainable value for the medium and long term.
And you know, I think when we have builders who are building for value creation and we have ecosystems that are really committed to funding true value creation over time as opposed to short-term hype metrics, then you know, we are starting to talk about a Crypto ecosystem that can drive real GDP, real value, that can invite more than 7,200 full-time builders and so on and so forth.
Are there any ecosystems that you think have done really well at that?
Most of the ecosystems that we're working with are committed to that in one way or another because that's, you know, that's practically our sales pitch, right?
And so I think that what we're noticing is that there is more and more ecosystem commitment to that on an ongoing basis.
I mean, one of our ecosystem partners is Zion, and I had a wonderful conversation yesterday with somebody in their foundation named Z about exactly that.
What does it mean to fund builders who create real value?
Because our commitment is to real value for the medium and long term, right?
And very consistently I'm hearing that directionally that's where foundations, you know, are going and frankly that's where they need to go.
Not just for, you know, the sake of their community or let's say their token price for the medium and long term, but really for the sake of an industry that has the opportunity to be like one of two fundamentally gamechanging industries in humanity, right, alongside AI.
But to do it, we need the real talent in this industry to not focus on value extraction and instead to be focused on creating and adding value to the system.
Yeah.
Do you think the sort of issue of value extraction is one of the biggest issues in Crypto?
Sort of one of the biggest things preventing it from growing even further?
Absolutely.
I mean, if you're a great mind coming into Crypto, I'm oversimplifying here, but you have two choices, and this is a really hard one.
Choice number two, choice number one is you can make a lot of money in the short term by extracting value from the ecosystem.
And that's what most great minds coming into Crypto do.
And it makes sense, right?
They can set their families up, you know, themselves, their communities up with generational wealth for, you know, in a very short amount of time.
And choice number two is that they can build something of real enduring value, right?
That also creates a lot of wealth for them, but is way harder and takes a lot longer.
And with most human beings, that's a difficult decision set, right?
With most human beings, even good human beings, they choose choice number one, right?
It's easier, right?
There's a very clear short-term path.
And you know, when Crypto gets enough people choosing choice number two, it's going to create enormous value, much more value than we could create with choice number one.
But we've got to get there.
Do you think it's changed over the years?
I feel like I want to say 2017, 2018.
Okay.
Obviously 2017 you had the ICO rush, you had a lot of people wanting to extract value, but I feel in general there were a lot of builders back then who were far more egalitarian who who sort of really wanted to I think just promote really like healthy growth.
Do you think it's changed much over the years?
I do think you see a lot of everyone being focused on value extraction these days, right?
Even if it's not as blatant as the sort of ICO mania.
I mean, it's pretty sad.
I have a really good friend who is a venture capitalist and this person has a portfolio of 150 or so investments that they've made over a number of years and they, you know, they were diamond hands, right?
And recently they told me that they came to the conclusion that the only good option is to as quickly as possible sell, right?
And that's a problem when you have people who have been in the ecosystem for years and years and years and years, right?
Who have been committed to the projects that they've been a part of.
And eventually they realize that if they're going to make any money in this industry, they have to figure out how to stop supporting those projects for the medium and long term, right?
And I see a lot of people who have been in Crypto for a while who eventually become exasperated with the space.
They realize that they have to, you know, do the same kinds of things that have worked for others, but they understood were bad for the industry.
And you know, and it's important for us to notice that and it's important for us to you know go wait a second there's something wrong with a lot.
There's something wrong with the way historically we've been thinking about tokconomics.
There's something, you know, wrong with the way that we've been thinking about how VCs win, you know, when they invest in projects, right?
Because often times for venture capitalists to make money off a project, they have to dump the token and there's not enough liquidity to support that project.
And so the venture capitalist wins but the project loses and that is an occurrence that is very very common in our space but that we need to figure out how to create a different path.
So there's a lot broken that we need to fix and unfortunately people who have been around for a while have been seeing it for a while.
There was a bit of controversy a while ago over whether or not VCs were good or bad for the space because obviously they do provide a lot of funding and provide a lot of support but ultimately their goal you know reasonably is to extract more value than they put in right?
I was curious, do you have a view on on VCs overall?
VCs in Crypto tend not to act like VCs in other industries, right?
They almost act more like hedge funds.
And you know, one of the things that I've noticed in general about VCs in Crypto is that in general they're not looking for real businesses that can create GDP for the industry, that can create real value for the industry.
They're looking for hype machines that, you know, they can sell the token as quickly as possible and make some money.
It's hard for me to call that a VC, right?
Like in our industry, we call them, they call themselves VCs, you know, etc.
But, you know, real venture capitalists that, you know, help support and build new industries and reap the rewards and benefits, what they do is they support great founders and great projects for the medium and long term, right?
And when those projects win in a really big way, they win in a really big way, too.
We don't have enough of that in Crypto.
If we had more of that in Crypto, you know, I think we'd see more sustainability in the ecosystem.
I do think the problem is is the fact that the the main goal is typically to get tokens as opposed to equity because I think the problem with a lot of tokens is partly due to the massively increasing number of tokens across the massively increasing number of blockchains.
There's so much dilution, it's just hard for tokens to to remain to to to keep their value or to increase their value in the long run.
And then in particular, even with well very popular projects that might be very widely used and have very good reputation in Crypto, the token price doesn't necessarily reflect that because partly because, you know, if it's a if it's a arguably pointless governance token, it's not capturing any of the value of the success of the protocol.
It can go in a complete opposite direction to the actual growth of the protocol.
So in a way it's you're not necessarily aligned with the success of the project in a way that I think typically you are if you have equity.
Yeah, I I I I I would agree with you and you know, I think that there is a real opportunity amongst the other problems that we talked about that need to be fixed to ensure that token value is aligned with project value.
Right?
It's a simple thing to say, but historically for regulatory reasons and other, right, it's been a really hard thing to do.
And hopefully as we get more clarity in the regulatory landscape, we can start really aligning those two pieces for most projects better.
And hopefully that'll help.
And you're right.
I mean, you know, when the pool is only so big, but you know, the number of tokens are increasing at such, you know, a massive rate on on almost a daily basis, it creates all kinds of issues, right?
From that that impact the viability of even good projects.
Yeah, I definitely think once you get rewards revenue sharing starts becoming much more commonplace, I think it then becomes much more interesting in buying tokens that you think are associated with projects that you think are have really good fundamentals.

You then suddenly actually, you know, start to think which which protocol is going to be here in 5 years time and how can I get a percentage of the fees it's going to make.
Um, yeah, I think we start to see some people call it Fundamental Season.
